content: The "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" addresses the serious international problem of operating submersible or semi-submersible vessels without nationality, which facilitates transnational crime, including drug trafficking and terrorism. It amends the United States Code to include regulations on the operation of such vessels. The "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" targets those who operate submersible or semi-submersible vessels without nationality in order to evade detection. The act defines submersible and semi-submersible vessels and imposes fines or imprisonment for violators. The "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" targets vessels without nationality, including manned or unmanned watercraft, to evade detection. It defines terms like 'vessel without nationality' and 'vessel of the United States' as per title 46. There is extraterritorial jurisdiction over offenses under this act, and a claim of nationality or registry is limited to possession on board the vessel. The "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" targets vessels without nationality, including manned or unmanned watercraft, to evade detection. It defines terms like 'vessel without nationality' and 'vessel of the United States' as per title 46. Possession of documents, flying the nation's flag, or a verbal claim of nationality by the vessel's master are ways to establish nationality. An affirmative defense is available to prove lawful registration in a foreign nation. The affirmative defenses under the "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" include proving that the vessel was classed by a classification society, operated in government-regulated activities, or equipped with specific tracking systems. These defenses are conclusively proved by the production of relevant documents. The "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" provides affirmative defenses, including government documents proving vessel nationality, classification certificates, and government licensure for research or exploration. Federal activities authorized by the US government are exempt from this section, and other provisions of title 46 also apply. The "Drug Trafficking Vessel Interdiction Act of 2008" provides affirmative defenses for vessel nationality, classification certificates, and government licensure. Federal activities authorized by the US government are exempt from this section, and provisions of title 46 also apply. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 111 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 4. SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission will create sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of operating submersible or semi-submersible vessels, ensuring penalties reflect the seriousness of the offense and the need for deterrence. The guidelines will consider aggravating or mitigating circumstances. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of using submersible or semi-submersible vessels in felonies, considering factors like repeated use, commercial organization involvement, violation patterns, and willful behavior of operators. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish sentencing guidelines for individuals convicted of using submersible or semi-submersible vessels in felonies, considering factors like repeated use, commercial organization involvement, violation patterns, and willful behavior of operators. The guidelines will ensure consistency with other directives, make necessary changes, and meet the purposes of sentencing as outlined in the law. The House of Representatives passed the legislation on July 29, 2008. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
